page.title: 10CHANGING TIMES:FARMING 2
page.content: Cows, ponies and sheep are kept. However sheep are the most important. Shetland Ponies are often transported out of the area to mainland Britain via Lerwick for children's horses. Lambing time is the busiest time of the year for all the farmers/crofters. It may start as early as January but usually occurs between April and June. Lambing is late in Sumburgh due to the severe winter weather. Later in the year the sheep have to be sheared, still traditionally done by hand. In late summer the sheep are dipped to get rid of unwanted pests. Crofting is a tradition, and the same piece of land has often been in the one family for generations. Some practices are purely local to Sumburgh.
